function_call.name: get_risks
function_call.arguments: {"risks":[{"Description":"Anomaly detection models relying on wearable technology data may not be device-agnostic, leading to limitations in generalizability and applicability to different devices.","Impact":"Limited generalizability and applicability to different wearable devices, reducing the effectiveness of the anomaly detection models.","Mitigation":"Develop device-agnostic anomaly detection models by incorporating data from multiple devices and standardizing data formats.","Technologies":"Data integration and standardization technologies for wearable devices, such as interoperable data formats and harmonization protocols.","People":"Developers, researchers, and manufacturers of wearable technology devices.","Owner":"Research institutions, industry organizations, and regulatory bodies."},{"Description":"Manual selection of physiological characteristics for anomaly detection model development may lead to biased or incomplete feature sets, impacting the effectiveness of the models.","Impact":"Biased or incomplete feature sets may reduce the accuracy and robustness of anomaly detection models, leading to higher false positive or false negative rates.","Mitigation":"Utilize automated feature extraction and selection techniques to ensure comprehensive and unbiased feature sets for model development.","Technologies":"Feature extraction and selection algorithms, machine learning-based feature engineering tools.","People":"Data scientists, machine learning engineers, and domain experts in physiological data analysis.","Owner":"Technology companies, research institutions, and healthcare organizations."},{"Description":"Limited external validation of anomaly detection models may result in overfitting to specific datasets, reducing the models' generalizability and reliability.","Impact":"Overfitting may lead to inflated performance metrics and misleading assessments of model effectiveness, limiting the real-world utility of the anomaly detection models.","Mitigation":"Conduct rigorous external validation using diverse and independent datasets to assess the generalizability and reliability of the anomaly detection models.","Technologies":"Cross-validation techniques, independent dataset validation frameworks, and ensemble learning methods for model evaluation.","People":"Data scientists, epidemiologists, and public health researchers.","Owner":"Healthcare institutions, public health agencies, and regulatory bodies."}]}
